displayed_text: Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down. Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get --

Patient: I ain’t got no problem with flying. Doctor: No. Go do it. Patient: I want that jet. Doctor: I know. Go get it. Patient: I want that jet. I get the jet I’m good. Doctor: You’ll have a great time. Patient: Yeah. I’m gonna have a great time on my bike. Doctor: Okay. Just be careful. People worry. That’s all. Patient: I know, I know. I know how to you know make her shut it down. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Call me if you run into trouble. If there’s issues with your insurance we will let you know. Patient: Well doc we ain’t claiming that. Remember you said that last time and we made it.

Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And plus that in addition to I was getting a little cramp in my side. And so we stopped. Doctor: Well with age, so-called metabolic syndrome increases in many people. And so what that means is you know your sugar levels become higher and um your metabolism changes in such a way as a result of that. And this may also cause other downstream effects on the down the line. For example, it might slightly increase the risk of having a cardio-vascular disease or a heart attack, for example, or cerebral-vascular disease like a stroke. If the blood glucose level is not controlled over time. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So all of the things that Metformin does is it changes your metabolism in such a way that the blood glucose level is lower and therefore it puts you at decreased risk of dying with those things that I mentioned. Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email- Patient: Yes. Doctor: -but as to you know, my Aximun scan is scheduled for this day. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then I can add you in for the following Tuesday. Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Without knowing when that schedule, there's probably not anybody there. So we'll see what that looks like.

Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe Doctor: One of my grand, great-grandmothers had a little thing on the side. I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, the joke is uh – Patient: He used to say that all the time, yeah. Doctor: Mommy’s baby, daddy’s maybe. Is that what I’ve heard? (Laughs) Family Member: It’s twenty-three and me --- Doctor: One of them tells you like how much Neanderthal you have. Ancestry didn’t tell you that. Family Member: It didn’t tell you --- Doctor: No, I wanted to know how much Neanderthal was in me. (Laughs) Doctor: Right, right. Patient: But that’s, uh, not so much the case anymore. That --- Doctor: Or how much – I’ve been watching these alien shows. I wanna learn how much alien Patient: Oh good, good.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation? Doctor: So we actually prefer it because we actually know how to treat your whole body systemically with all these medicines from the chemist. (whistle noise) Patient: Right. Doctor: With these medicines, but we also, and it also gives you more time to heal. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: From the surgery, which is better for you as far as long-term side effects. Family Member: Uh hum. Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I made a copy for you so you can, um, this, this has a pretty good amount of information. Family Member: We get to keep this? Doctor: Yeah. It’s yours – it’s all, it’s in our computer. Family Member: So, keep the appointments that we have already? Like the hormone shot in January. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: And, there’s something else? Patient: Is this in my chart? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I just printed it out. Family Member: Uh, yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes.

Family Member: And he’s not walking this time. He has an unsteady gait. He’s stumbling. Doctor: No? Really? Patient: No I ain’t walking the same. Family Member: And I told him he’s a fall risk so I’d like him to take his cane with him. He says well it’s in my truck, but you can fall going from the house to your truck. Doctor: I agree. Better to keep it. Family Member: Period. Doctor: It’s still better than having to use a walker otherwise. So that’s… Family Member: I’m not walking outside with that cane. That’s what you told me last week. And I said alright just go ahead and fall because I’m not coming out to get you. I don’t want to see you hurt that’s why I think preventive measures Doctor: A fracture now would really set us back. So- Family Member: Yes because we have brittle bones. Doctor: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often. Family Member: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ -

Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ve got to find out about that. Those are the two I’m going to look at. Okay? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then I’m going to look at what is the Xtandi going to cost us, and, you know, hopefully within the next two days, I’ll have the answer to all that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If you know, for medical expenses Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Alright Family Member: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input. Doctor: Of course. Family Member: Because J___ listens to you. Doctor: Yeah and he’s doing much better too. Family Member: Yes, he is. Doctor: So the cancer meds do you have enough or are you gonna need a refill. Family Member: We have one refill left. When do we come back here?

Patient: Mmm Doctor: wanna do anything, you don’t, you know if there’s anything that sort of Patient: No. And, and with the kind of work that I do, it’s not unusual to get in at two or three in the morning, have to get up at six in the morning, and you just, you have to drive on. You sleep for three hours in the afternoon, and then you go to work at six at night and work until eleven. And then, it, it just is part of what I do. Um, so. Doctor: Okay. And, uh, last time we talked - Family Member: So, as a, a young man he worked the night shifts- Patient: Oh, yeah. Family Member: So he had Patient: For eight years. Family Member: Weird sleep rhythms then. And then he, he did, um, move into a period of time where he worked a more normal, more universal schedule. Yeah and then started this, you know, this investigation thing which is very, sometimes it’s very haphazard. Doctor: Okay. Well, last time you were talking about kidney stone pain and that you felt like you were peeing razor blades. Patient: Yes, none. That had happened, maybe two more pees. (Laughs) Doctor: And, have you been to the hospital?

Patient: Potassium. Doctor: That's right. That's for the secondary causes of hypertension. Okay. Okay, so that is, so that's that approach. The third approach is clinical trials. And clinical trials in general are where we're testing some intervention to see if it is helpful or not. The two that we have for people who have biochemical recurrence, there's one that's a natural products. And there's one that is a medicine called a PARP inhibitor. Patient: Mm. Doctor: The mainstay of treatment of prostate cancer today is hormone therapy, neither of those two therapies are hormone therapy. Okay, so the clinical trials that we have would be doing, they would be giving you some intervention, but it would not be a hormone therapy intervention. So sometimes people like that because they don't want to get started on hormone therapy. Because if your disease progresses, you got to get started on hormone therapy- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: -and sometimes people, you know, don't want to be in a clinical trial. And so these are, the three general options. Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 3 years (2 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 3 years (2 years but less than 3 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: They ain’t doin’ any… (pause4sec) Doctor: And pain wise I have to give you the one hundred eighty right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think you’ve reminded me after now enough that (laughs) Healthcare Professional: I think he’s on morphine sixty? Doctor: Is he authorized for the Okay. Patient: Oh out here? Doctor: No or when you go over for treatment you can hand it to your nurse Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they can make all the schedule for you. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So you don’t have to wait here. Patient: Right.

Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter) Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point.
